factoid: Nicholas expressed disapproval of postponing the marriage for a year.
Natásha attacked Natásha's brother with exasperation.
Natásha proved to Natásha's brother that the postponement could not be otherwise.
Natásha proved to Natásha's brother that it would be a bad thing to enter a family against the father's will.
Natásha proved to Natásha's brother that she herself wished the postponement.
Natásha said "You don't at all understand."
Nicholas was silent.
Nicholas agreed with Natásha.
Natásha's brother often wondered while looking at Natásha.
Natásha did not seem like a girl in love.
Natásha departed from her affianced husband.
Natásha was even-tempered.
Natásha was calm.
Natásha was cheerful as of old.
Nicholas was amazed by Natásha's demeanor.
Nicholas regarded Bolkónski's courtship skeptically.
Nicholas could not believe that Natásha's fate was sealed.
Nicholas had not seen Natásha with Prince Andrew.
Nicholas thought something was not quite right about the intended marriage.
Nicholas thought "Why this delay? Why no betrothal?"
Nicholas discovered that Natásha's mother also had doubts about the marriage.
Natásha's mother showed her son a letter from Prince Andrew.
The letter said Prince Andrew would not come before December.
The letter suggested illness might be keeping Prince Andrew.
Prince Andrew's health is very delicate.
Natásha's mother told her son not to tell Natásha.
Natásha's mother told her son not to attach importance to Natásha being bright.
Natásha's mother said Natásha is living through the last days of her girlhood.
Natásha's mother said she knows what Natásha is like every time they receive a letter from Prince Andrew.
Natásha's mother said God grant everything turns out well.
Natásha's mother always ended her remarks with those words.
Natásha's mother said Prince Andrew is an excellent man.
Nicholas reached home and was serious and dull.
Nicholas was worried about interfering in business matters for which his mother had called him home.
On the third day after his arrival, Nicholas went to Mítenka’s lodge angry and scowling.
Nicholas demanded an account of everything from Mítenka.
Nicholas knew less than Mítenka about what an account of everything might be.
The conversation between Nicholas and Mítenka did not last long.
The village elder, a peasant delegate, and the village clerk were waiting in the passage.
The elder, delegate, and clerk heard the young count’s voice roaring and snapping.
The elder, delegate, and clerk heard words of abuse from the young count.
The young count shouted "Robber! Ungrateful wretch! I'll hack the dog to pieces! I'm not my father! Robbing us!"
The young count was red in the face and had bloodshot eyes.
The young count dragged Mítenka out by the scruff of the neck.
The young count applied his foot and knee to Mítenka's behind.
The young count shouted "Be off! Never let me see your face here again, you villain!"
Mítenka ran down the six steps and into the shrubbery.
The shrubbery was a well-known haven of refuge for culprits at Otrádnoe.
Mítenka used to hide in the shrubbery when returning tipsy from town.
Many residents at Otrádnoe knew the shrubbery had protective qualities.
Mítenka’s wife and sisters-in-law thrust their heads and frightened faces out of the door of a room with a bright samovar boiling.
The room also had the steward’s high bedstead with a patchwork quilt.
The young count passed by the wife and sisters-in-law without paying heed.
The young count passed by breathing hard and went into the house.
The countess heard from the maids what had happened at the lodge.
The countess was calmed by the thought that their affairs would improve.
The countess felt anxious about the effect of the excitement on her son.
The countess went several times to her son's door on tiptoe.
The countess listened as her son lit one pipe after another.
The old count called his son aside the next day.
The old count had an embarrassed smile.
The old count said "It's a pity you got excited."
The old count said Mítenka has told him all about it.
Nicholas thought "I knew that I should never understand anything in this crazy world."
